qas.question: When did the Democratic Movement of Moldova start operating?
Which monument was a popular meeting place?
Where was the Stephen the Great Monument located?
What did the movement seek to make the official language of Moldova?

context: Beginning in <a0_0>February 1988<a0_0/>, the Democratic Movement of Moldova (formerly <a4_0>Moldavia<a4_0/>) organized public meetings, demonstrations, and song festivals, which gradually grew in size and intensity. In the streets, the center of public manifestations was the <a1_0>Stephen the Great Monument<a1_0/> in <a2_0>Chişinău<a2_0/>, and the adjacent park harboring Aleea Clasicilor (The "Alee of the Classics [of the Literature]"). On January 15, 1988, in a tribute to Mihai Eminescu at his bust on the Aleea Clasicilor, Anatol Şalaru submitted a proposal to continue the meetings. In the public discourse, the movement called for national awakening, freedom of speech, revival of Moldavian traditions, and for attainment of official status for the <a3_0>Romanian<a3_0/> language and return to the Latin alphabet. The transition from "movement" (an informal association) to "front" (a formal association) was seen as a natural "upgrade" once a movement gained momentum with the public, and the Soviet authorities no longer dared to crack down on it.
